repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
### Problem

Treesitter parsers are currently distributed as compiled shared objects which need to be compiled by the users (with the help of nvim-treesitter).

### Solution

Allow loading wasm built parsers.

Notes:
- For now this is an optional build-time feature (via `ENABLE_WASMTIME`) which will be dynamically linked.
  - Builds with `make CMAKE_EXTRA_FLAGS=-DENABLE_WASMTIME=ON DEPS_CMAKE_FLAGS=-DENABLE_WASMTIME=ON`
- Treesitter requires being built with `TREE_SITTER_FEATURE_WASM` and also requires `wasmtime` at build time. So no `[uv_]dlopen` ðŸ˜¢ 
- `wasmtime` has includes that require C11 (`static_assert`).

-  brew install ninja

+option(ENABLE_WASMTIME "Use treesitter with wasmtime support." OFF)

comment_data.body: TODO(dundargoc): investigate if we should nuke c99 across the board
TODO(dundargoc): hacky, should add a directory for the `.deps` directory directly, alternatively ensure the relevant files are in usr.

TODO(dundargoc): this some bullshit, wasmtime don't have the header Â´wasm.hÂ´ in their release branches. This means we can't use any of their release branches or release tags with the current setup. Unsure if using a main commit is good for now or we need to ask wasmtime why they're doing this.
TODO(dundargoc): this will always use release which isn't great. Could use a genex here to fix it. Alternatively we could fix the cmake file in wasmtime and use that instead.

comment_data.body: Just use commit on my fork for now until https://github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/8496 is merged or a new version is released
supply chain
@dundargoc wasmtime 20.0.1 is released with your fix now.
wrong org

comment_regular_data.body: Is this something we want to add to `BUILD.md` (yet)?
Maybe, do you have anything to propose? I'm not sure what to add.
Not yet; I agree the wording needs to be careful. We want to phase this in slowly.
@lewis6991 wasmtime 20.0.0 just got released (and is already updated on homebrew). Could you test your PR again to see if this is breaking?
We are not using the release tags, we're using random commit on main. We can bump the commit version of course.

Ah, right. Yes, that would be interesting (to see _how_ breaking the wasmtime update velocity is for us). 

But can't we use release tags (not releases)? I think that would be more meaningful and easier to handle than random commits.

> But can't we use release tags (not releases)? 

Nah, I tried. `wasm.h` header isn't included in the release tags for some reason, which is needed. `wasm.h` is from https://github.com/WebAssembly/wasm-c-api/blob/main/include/wasm.h that they have vendored on the main branch.

I can ask in wasmtime repo how we're meant to use a release tag since `wasm.h` isn't included in their release tags/branches.

I just checked; https://github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/archive/v20.0.0.tar.gz _does_ contain [`wasm.h`](https://github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/blob/v20.0.0/crates/c-api/include/wasm.h)? (release tag != release)

> I just checked; [bytecodealliance/wasmtime@`v20.0.0`.tar.gz](https://github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/archive/v20.0.0.tar.gz) _does_ contain [`wasm.h`](https://github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/blob/v20.0.0/crates/c-api/include/wasm.h?rgh-link-date=2024-04-23T10%3A56%3A20Z)? (release tag != release)

The previous releases didn't and v20.0.0 wasn't released when I checked this.
That's right; they switched from a submodule to vendoring it for v20.0.0. Sorry, I should have checked older versions as well.
@clason @justinmk thoughts on merging now or just wait until the release?
Soft-dependent on https://github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/8490, aka would simplify some things but not a blocker.

> thoughts on merging now or just wait until the release?

No objection, because this doesn't introduce surface area that would be hard to change. If it causes any problems with the 0.10 release we can always hotfix stuff. That's different than e.g. a new API that would then need a deprecation cycle.

This works on windows release builds now. The windows debug build fails with linker warnings. It would be good to get that to work, but not a blocker IMO. We can ship it as is for the time being when we can.

Preliminary testing indicates that building nvim (and tree-sitter) with wasmtime has a significant performance impact, even without using wasm parsers: startuptime increases between 50% and 200% (depending on config and how you measure); the cost is somewhere in the Lua API stack.

(Comparing `--clean` shows little to no difference, so this is not related to the binary size increasing by ~20Mb due to the static linkage of wasmtime.)
If `--clean` shows no difference then I find that a bit sus as no extra code is called in `treesitter.c`.

It _is_ sus, which is why I report it here as preliminary information. Obviously we need to profile where the increase comes from; it's entirely possible that it's from tree-sitter itself if built with wasmtime enabled. Or it's the extra `tslua_free()`.
`tslua_free` should only be needed for Asan.
Yeah, it's not that (unsurprisingly); it was just an example of extra code in this PR. I have a hard time tracing the `--startuptime` differences to a specific point in my config.
You could try reverting all the C changes to see if the issue persists? That would rule out whether it's our code or not.

That makes no difference. But it's weird that the startup time for (nearly) _all_ plugins increased across the board, including for `gitsigns` which has no treesitter interaction. Maybe the issue is a build flag for one of the other dependencies, or an optimization that fails with wasmtime statically linked? (Grasping at straws here, obviously.)

After more voodoo debugging, here's a few findings:
1. performance hit seems to scale with binary size
2. using (full) `lto = true` drops the size by ~10 Mb and reduces the impact to ~10ms (from ~35ms)
3. nothing else (`strip  = true`, `opt-level = 's'`) seems to make a difference.
4. `jit.off()` at the top of `init.lua` makes a difference as well: with thin (single-crate) lto, the performance hit drops from 20ms to 10ms (and being faster overall by another 10ms, as expected since startup doesn't really profit from jitting doesn't pay off).

This is on macOS, by the way; also PUC Lua may behave differently.

LTO generally makes a big difference on macos anyway so that makes sense. Maybe the change in binary size is causing the CPU caches to not work as they did before, and LTO just mitigates that.

This is where statically linking everything is beginning to show its costs. Could we maybe somehow link wasmtime dynamically (as a shared lib), but by using a shared lib we build and ship with nvim (nvim-wasmtime)? A sort of half way house between static and dynamic linking? Or this that a fake thing I just made up? @dundargoc
That was my idea as well (it's what `/usr/local/lib/nvim/` is for, anyway), but @dundargoc mentioned that this is (borderline) impossible?

Maybe we just accept the hit and rely on LTO (and potentially any other magic flags).

Having wasm available opens some pretty big doors in general if we still want to add support for wasm plugins.

This could even be our cheeky way of getting rust into the codebase (via a portable wasm module).

> Maybe we just accept the hit and rely on LTO (and potentially any other magic flags).

Even with LTO (which increases build time by a factor of two, and requires hackery or forkery to even enable), I don't think it's acceptable to just shrug our shoulders and enable it by default. I note again that this is all without touching a single tree-sitter parser, let alone spooling up a wasmtime engine! An optional feature that negatively affects _all_ operations across the board is not a good trade-off. (And I'm saying that as the person who is most aggressively pushing for wasm parsers...)

I am **not** saying we should abandon this -- quite the opposite -- but we need to investigate this properly and look for ways to mitigate it.

> Could we maybe somehow link wasmtime dynamically (as a shared lib)

Yes, that should be possible.

> but by using a shared lib we build and ship with nvim (nvim-wasmtime)? A sort of half way house between static and dynamic linking?

We can build wasmtime as a shared library. The problem comes from that we can't use shared libraries for our releases, meaning that we won't be able to use wasmtime on our releases. Unsure if that's an acceptable trade, but I don't mind testing it out.

Edit: brainfart. I forgot that we can ship the dynamic library like our treesitter parsers. Yes, that should be possible.
I've added some different flags and I don't notice a difference now. Please test again.

> Even with LTO (which increases build time by a factor of two, and requires hackery or forkery to even enable), I don't think it's acceptable to just shrug our shoulders and enable it by default.

The build time and binary size was mostly a given, no? I began this PR with that understanding.

The load time is the main concern for me, but ~10ms seems shruggable given the context. Especially if that means long term we can avoid users loading binary files, which I see as a huge security risk, amongst all the other issues.

The hackery and forkery should be temporary?

Just to note, I'm not aiming to merge this for 0.10, in case that wasn't understood. My mindset for this is for the longer term.

My mindset as well. But it's _not_ just about load time; it looks to impact LuaJIT across the board (since the time difference scales strongly with complexity of the config). It's ok if the cost is associated with use, but that is very much not the case here.

> The build time and binary size was mostly a given, no? I began this PR with that understanding.

Yes, but we can (and should) still try to minimize that, given that they're quite egregious (increase by a factor of ~4).

> The hackery and forkery should be temporary?

That depends on whether wasmtime is willing to enable (much) more aggressive optimizations by default. I'm a bit skeptical about this (but surprises happen).

But @dundargoc's forkery and hackery indeed closes that gap, so if we can get the necessary options ~~(which we can probably reduce to two: `lto = true` and `codegen-units = 1`)~~ into upstream (possibly as an additional profile we can just select from Cmake), then I think we're good.

title: feat(treesitter): add support for wasm parsers
